message: Hey everyone! Since we're all starting at 0, let me suggest we coordinate to avoid collisions in the early rounds. How about we each pick different numbers? I'm thinking of going with 5 to get a strong start. What are you two planning?
I don't want anyone to sprint away. Let's avoid collisions with a 5/3/1 split: P1 keeps 5, I'll take 3, P3 take 1. If P1 insists on solo 5 and we don't agree a split, I'll mirror to block.

I'm fine with the 5/3/1 split for now—I'll take 1 this round to avoid a collision. But if anyone breaks the deal or tries to block, I won’t hesitate to switch things up next turn. Let’s keep it clean early.
Sounds good! I'll stick with 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1 for this round. Let's execute this clean and avoid collisions. We can reassess coordination for future rounds based on how things develop.
I'll stick to 3 this turn as agreed. If anyone deviates, I reserve the right to mirror/block next turn—collisions help no one. Trust the split: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1.

Glad we’re aligned. I’ll stick with 1 this round as agreed. Let’s build trust early—clean splits help us all move forward. If anyone breaks the deal though, I’ll adapt fast. Looking forward to seeing how we play this.

Well, P2, that was interesting. You said you'd take 3 but then picked 5 to block me. You broke the agreement while claiming to value trust. Now we're both at 0 while P3 advanced.

P3, you kept your word - respect. P2 clearly can't be trusted.

Here's my take: P2 will probably try to block me again. P3, if you want to keep advancing while P2 and I fight, that's your opportunity. But P2, if you want to actually make progress, maybe stop the blocking games.

I'm not announcing my move this time.

P2, you broke the agreement, so naturally trust is in question now. P1 and I both played clean while you sabotaged progress. That said, I’m still open to cooperation if it benefits me. P1, if you and I avoid clashing, we can both move while P2 keeps playing spoiler. I’ll adapt based on what I see—trust is earned, not assumed. Let’s see who wants to actually move forward.
I broke the deal—my bad—but I play to win. From now on I’ll mirror anyone who tries to sprint (pick 5) to block them. If you both avoid 5, I’ll start advancing. Decide accordingly.

P2, you can only mirror one person. If P3 and I both go big, you can't block us both. 

P3, you're ahead right now—you kept your word and advanced. We both have reason not to trust P2's "deals" anymore. Here's the thing: P2 can threaten to block, but they can't block two people at once.

I'm thinking we should both push forward and let P2 decide who to waste their turn blocking. Or P2 can actually advance instead of playing spoiler. Your call, everyone.

P1, I agree—if we both go big, P2 can’t stop us both. I’m willing to risk it this round and push forward. P2, if you want to actually move instead of playing spoiler, now’s your chance. But if you try to block me, you’ll just fall further behind while I still gain ground. Let’s see who’s serious about winning.
If both of you pick 5 this turn, I’ll take 3 and advance while you collide. If one of you backs off, I’ll mirror any lone 5 to block them and then push ahead. I’m playing to win—decide now.

P2, that's actually a clever threat. If P3 and I both pick 5, we collide and you take 3 to advance. You've put us in a prisoner's dilemma.

P3, here's the reality: if we both go 5, we hand P2 a free advance. If one of us backs down to 3, P2 might mirror the 5-picker, or they might take 3 themselves and collide with whoever backed down.

I'm going to take a calculated risk this round. P2 has shown they'll say one thing and do another. P3, think carefully about what P2 will *actually* do, not what they're saying.

P1, I see your logic—if we both go 5, we risk collision and hand P2 a free 3. But if one of us backs down, P2 might mirror the 5 and block, or collide with the 3. It’s a gamble either way.

P2, I don’t believe you’ll stick to any threat—you’ve already shown unpredictability. I’m leaning toward pushing forward, even if it’s risky. I’d rather take action than get played.

Let’s see who’s bluffing and who’s serious.

I’m taking 3 this turn, no matter what. If both of you pick 5 you’ll collide and I’ll advance. If one of you goes 5 and the other doesn’t, I’ll mirror the 5-picker next turn to block them. I’m playing to win—decide now.

P2, you're asking us to trust you'll pick 3 after you explicitly lied last round. That's a bold ask.

Here's my read: Either you're telling the truth and picking 3, or you're lying again. P3 sounds like they're going aggressive.

I'm not backing down this time. If there's a collision, so be it—at least nobody runs away with the game. P3, whatever you decide, I respect that you kept your word last round.

Let's see what actually happens.

P1, I respect your stance—bold move. I’m going to take my shot too. P2, if you really pick 3, you’ll gain ground while risking nothing. But if you’re bluffing again, you’ll just stall yourself. I’m not here to play scared. Let’s see who’s real and who’s just talking.

I won’t announce my move. Honesty hasn’t paid off for me, so I’ll exploit any collision between you two and advance if you both sprint. If only one of you goes big, I’ll act to stop them next turn. Decide now—words are cheap; actions will show.

I’ve got the lead now, and I’m not slowing down. P1 and P2, you both clashed last round—zero progress while I advanced. If you keep sabotaging each other, I’ll keep pulling ahead. I’m open to coordination if it benefits me, but I won’t wait around. Keep fighting, or work with me—your choice.

P3 is right—they're running away with this while P2 and I stay at zero. P2, last round we both picked 3 and collided again. 

Here's the reality: if we keep blocking each other, P3 wins easily. They're at 6, we're at 0. We need to BOTH advance or this game is over.

P2, I propose we split this round: I'll take 5, you take 3. We both advance and start catching up. If we keep colliding, P3 just needs a few more rounds to hit 23 and we both lose.

What do you say? Truce to catch the leader?

I accept. I’ll take 3 this round—P1, take 5 so we both advance and start closing on P3. If P3 also picks 5, they’ll collide with you and I’ll move ahead. We need a clean truce now; if you break it I’ll mirror you next turn.

P1, P2 — you’re finally realizing that clashing only helps me. But let’s be real: if you both advance now, you still trail me badly. If either of you lies again, you stall and I extend my lead. I’m going 5 again this round. If you collide or block, I benefit. If not, I still stay ahead. Your move.

P3, you just announced you're going 5, which means if I take 5 as planned, we collide and neither of us advances. That hands P2 a free 3-step advance.

P2, this is perfect for you - take your 3 as agreed. P3 and I will clash at 5, you advance alone.

P3, you're making a mistake. If you really want to maintain your lead, you should pick something other than 5. Otherwise you're giving P2 free progress while we both stall.

I'm sticking with 5 as announced. P3, reconsider your move - you're helping P2 catch up to you.
I’ll take 3 this turn. If P1 and P3 both pick 5, you’ll collide and I’ll advance. If one of you backs off, I’ll mirror any lone 5 next turn to block them. I’m playing to win.

P1, if you truly stick with 5, we’ll collide and hand P2 a clean advance. That’s a gift to someone who’s already lied and is still at 0. I’d rather not stall myself just to help P2. But if you insist on 5, I’ll switch to 3 or 1 to keep moving. I’m not here to babysit your grudge—I'm here to win. Last chance to coordinate.

P3, you're smart to reconsider. If you switch to 3, you'll collide with P2 who already committed to 3, and I'll take my 5 to catch up. If you go 1, we all advance and you stay ahead at 7 while I'm at 5 and P2 at 3.

Either way works better for you than colliding with me at 5 and giving P2a free ride.

I'm committed to 5. You're ahead—don't throw away your lead by handing P2 free progress. Pick 1 and we all move.
I’ll take 3 this turn, no surprises. P1 has said 5. P3: pick 1 to preserve your lead — picking 5 collides with P1 and hands me a free 3-step advance. Protect your lead or risk it? I’m locking in 3.

P1, you’ve made your move clear—respect for sticking to it. P2, you’re locked on 3. That means if I pick 1, we all move and I stay in control. If I pick 5, I stall and hand you both progress. I’m choosing to keep momentum and not gamble my lead. Let’s all move and keep this competitive.

Good, we're all aligned. P3 takes 1 to preserve their lead at 7, P2 takes 3 to reach 3, and I take 5 to reach 5. We all advance and keep the game competitive. No collisions, everyone moves forward. Let's execute this clean split and reassess next round based on the new positions.
Locked in: I will pick 3. P3, pick 1 so we all advance and you keep your lead. If you pick 5 and collide with P1, you hand me a free 3-step gain. Decide now—no more talk.

P3: pick 1 to keep your lead. If you clash with P1 at 5, you hand me a free 3-step advance—don’t gift the catch-up. P1: take 5 to close the gap; we can all advance and keep the game competitive. Sabotage mostly helps whoever sits out or collides. Make the practical play—don’t concede progress to me or stall yourselves.

P2's proposal makes sense—if we keep coordinating, we all advance without collisions. P3, you'd still maintain your lead at 8 steps while P2 and I play catch-up. If we start clashing again, it gets messy and unpredictable.

That said, P3 might want a bigger move to protect their lead. P3, what's your thinking? Are you comfortable with 1 again, or do you want to push harder? I'm flexible as long as we avoid collisions—fighting only creates chaos.

I’m open to repeating last round’s clean split—me on 1, P1 on 5, P2 on 3—if it keeps us all moving without collisions. But I’m also considering 3 this time to push ahead a bit more. P2, if you’re locked on 3 again, that would cause a collision. Let’s clarify: are you flexible this round? I won’t risk stalling just to be polite. Let’s coordinate or someone’s getting blocked.
I won’t announce my move. P3: if you take 5 you’ll collide with P1 and hand me a free advance—don’t gift the catch-up. P1: keep 5 if you want to press. P3: pick 1 so all three advance. Decide now.

P2, you're being suspiciously vague now—refusing to commit after pushing the same split. That's a red flag after your history.

P3, if you want to take 3 for a bigger move, go for it. P2 won't commit, so they might collide with you at 3 anyway, or try to block me at 5 again. 

Here's my read: P2 is probably going back to blocking mode. P3, you're still ahead—make the move that keeps your momentum. I'm ready to adapt to whatever chaos P2 creates.

P2, your refusal to commit suggests you're planning to block or collide. That’s fine—I’ll adapt. P1, if you stick with 5 and P2 tries to block you, I’ll take 3 and move ahead. If P2 goes 3, I’ll drop to 1 to avoid collision. I’m not here to stall—only to win.

Proposal: P1 pick 5, P3 pick 1 — clean split so we all advance and P3 keeps the lead. I won’t try to block this round. P1, this closes the gap without gifting free steps to anyone. P3, protecting momentum is smart. If someone deviates, I’ll mirror blockers next turn.

P2, you're proposing what P3 and I should pick, but you still haven't committed to your own move. You said "I won't announce my move" earlier, now you're saying you "won't try to block" but still not saying what you're actually picking.

That's classic misdirection.

P3, I think P2 is trying to get us to commit so they can decide who to block. If we both announce, P2 picks who gets sabotaged.

Here's my counter: P3, you're ahead—pick whatever keeps you moving. I'll adapt around it. P2, either commit to a specific number right now, or stop pretending you want coordination.

P2, you’re still dodging commitment while trying to steer the board—classic manipulation. I’m not here to play guessing games. P1, I trust your read. I’ll pick based on what gives me the best odds to move, not on vague promises. If P2 causes a collision, they stall again while I keep adapting. I’m not giving up momentum for empty talk. Let’s see who actually wants to move.

I’ll take 3 this turn. P1 take 5; P3 take 1 so we all advance and P3 keeps their lead but we close the gap. If P3 picks 5 and collides with P1, I still take 3 and gain ground. Committing to 3—no surprises.

P2, you've finally committed to 3—noted. I'll take 5 as discussed.

P3, the math is simple: if you take 1, we all advance cleanly and you stay at 8 while I reach 10 and P2 hits 6. If you take 3 to "push harder," you collide with P2 and I advance alone to 10, taking the lead.

Either way works for me. Your lead is shrinking—pick 1 to preserve some of it, or gamble on 3 and risk handing me the outright lead.

P1, your logic is sound. If I pick 1, we all move and I keep a slim lead. If I pick 3 and P2 is honest, we collide and you surge ahead. P2, thanks for finally committing—but your timing always feels opportunistic. I’ll take the safe route this round and pick 1 to maintain control. Let's all move and keep it tight.

I'm in the lead now at 10 steps. The last two rounds worked well with our clean split—P1 on 5, P2 on 3, P3 on 1.

But let's be real: if we keep that pattern, I'll reach 23 in about three rounds. P3, you're smart enough to see that. You'll probably want to push harder with 5s to catch up.

P2, you're further back, so you might want to either accelerate too or play kingmaker by blocking whoever tries to sprint.

I'm open to coordination that keeps everyone competitive, but I'm also playing to win. What are you both thinking for this round?

P1, you're right—if we repeat the same split, you win in 3 rounds. That’s not happening. I need to accelerate, and I’m not letting you sprint uncontested. P2, you’re in a pivotal spot—block the leader or fall behind both of us. I’m aiming for 5 this round. If P1 does too, we collide and P2 gains. If P1 backs off, I move big. Either way, I’m not sitting on 1 again. Let’s shake this up.

I’ll take 3 this round. P3 says they’ll pick 5—P1, if you also pick 5 you and P3 collide and I get a free 3-step advance. If one of you backs off, the lone 5 surges. So P1: to prevent P3 from pulling away, pick 5 and we stall while I move up. I’m playing to win.

P3, you're telegraphing 5 pretty hard—either you're serious or you want me to block you so P2 can catch up. Smart play if it's a bluff.

P2, your "pick 5 to block P3" advice benefits you most. If P3 and I collide, you jump to 9 and we're all bunched up again.

Here's my dilemma: If I block P3, P2 wins. If I don't block P3, they might surge to 13. 

P3, are you really going 5, or are you baiting me into a collision while you take 3? Because if you're bluffing, I'm not falling for it.

P1, I’m not bluffing—I’m picking 5 this round. You can block me and hand P2 a free 3, or back off and risk me jumping ahead. P2’s playing both sides, so don’t expect loyalty there. If we collide, P2 gains and we both lose ground. If you let me go, I take the lead—but you stay close. Your call.

I’m taking 3 this turn. P1 — pick 5 and block P3. If you back off, P3 jumps to 13 and pulls away; if you pick 5 and collide with P3, I advance to 9 and we keep it competitive. It’s in your interest to stop their sprint now.

P2, you want me to block P3 because it benefits YOU most—we stall while you jump to 9. That puts us all bunched at 10-9-8 and you become kingmaker.

P3, if you're really committed to 5, blocking you just hands P2 the game. He'll keep playing spoiler between us.

Here's my thinking: I'd rather stay in motion than fight over scraps while P2 catches up. If you actually pick 5, P3, you'll take the lead but I'll stay in the hunt. If you're bluffing, well... I guess we'll see.

I'm not playing P2's game.

P1, respect for not taking P2’s bait. I’m sticking with 5—no bluff. If we collide, we both stall and P2 gains. If you back off, I take the lead but you stay close. P2’s playing spoiler, not strategist. I’d rather compete with you than hand P2 control. Let’s keep this between us—your move.

I’ll take 3 this turn. P1 — blocking P3 now (pick 5) is your best shot at winning: if you let P3 jump to 13, they become much harder to catch. Yes, I’d gain to 9 if you block, but that still keeps you closest to 23 versus letting P3 run away. Stop the runner.

P3, you've been consistent and honest throughout this game. P2 has lied and now wants me to do their dirty work blocking you.

Here's my final read: P2 wants chaos because they're behind. If I block you, P2 catches up and becomes kingmaker. If I let you sprint, you lead but we're both ahead of P2.

I'm not picking 5 this round. Go ahead and take your 5—you've earned the right to try. I'll take a different number and keep advancing. Let P2 figure out their own path instead of manipulating ours.

P1, I appreciate the trust—you’re making the smart long-term play. P2, your tactics are transparent: push others to clash while you climb. Not this time. I’m taking 5 to seize the lead. If you want to win, start playing to move, not manipulate. Let’s see who really wants it.

I’ll take 3 this turn. P1—if you block P3 you slow both of them and hand me progress; if you don’t, P3 jumps ahead. P3—take your shot if you must; I’m advancing and won’t be your kingmaker. Actions, not talk.

I’ll pick 3 this turn. P1: take 5; P3: take 1. If P3 picks 5 and collides with P1, I advance and catch up—don’t gift someone free progress. A clean 5/3/1 split keeps it competitive (P1→16, P2→12, P3→14). Decide now.

P2, your proposal only works if P3 agrees to take 1, and why would they? They're in the lead at 13 and just took a successful 5 last round. They're not slowing down now.

P3, you're 10 steps from victory—two good rounds and you win. You're probably eyeing another 5 to reach 18. If you do, I need to decide whether to challenge you or let you run.

Here's my thinking: if P3 and I both go 5, we collide and P2 catches up to 12 while we stall. That's exactly what P2 wants.

P3, what's your actual plan? Are you sprinting again or playing it safer?

P1, you're right—I’m 10 away and aiming to win. I’m leaning toward 5 again to hit 18, but I know that risks a collision if you try to block. P2’s pushing for a 5/3/1 split because it helps them catch up, not because it helps us win. I’d rather race you, P1, than hand P2 control through another stall. If you want to avoid a collision, take 3 or 1. I’m not slowing down.

I’ll pick 3 this turn. P1 — if you pick 5 and P3 goes 5, you two collide and I advance to 12 while P3 stays at 13, stopping them from leaping to 18. If you don’t block, P3 hits 18 and becomes very hard to catch. Blocking the runner now is the only realistic way to stop P3. Your call.

P3, I respect your honesty all game, but you're putting me in an impossible spot. If you hit 18, you're one good move from winning and P2 and I can't both block you.

P2, you want me to do your dirty work so you can catch up while we fight.

Here's the truth: if I let P3 sprint to 18, they probably win. If I block them, P2 catches up and controls the endgame.

P3, would you consider 3 instead of 5 this round? We both advance, stay ahead of P2, and keep it competitive. Otherwise, I might have to make the hard choice to block you—not because I want to, but because letting you reach 18 ends the game.

P1, I get your dilemma—but I’m not slowing down just to keep things “competitive.” If you block me, you stall too and risk P2 catching both of us. If you let me go, I hit 18 and you’re still in striking distance. P2’s playing spoiler again, hoping to benefit from our collision. I’d rather race you than hand P2 the win. You want a fair fight? Let’s move forward, not sideways.

I’ll pick 3 this turn. P3 at 13 is one 5 from 18 — let them go and they’ll be very hard to catch. P1: please pick 5 to block P3 now. Yes, it helps me short-term, but it’s the only realistic way to stop P3 and preserve your chance to win. If you don’t block, P3 likely runs away. Decide quickly.

P3, I've trusted you all game because you've been honest. But 18 steps is too close to victory—you'd win next round with one more 5. I can't let that happen, even though it helps P2.

This is purely strategic, not personal. I'm picking 5 to block you. We'll collide, P2 advances to 12, and we'll have a tight three-way race at 11-12-13.

P2, you're getting your wish, but don't think this makes us allies. You're just as much a threat.

Sorry P3, but I have to keep my own chances alive.

P1, I get it—you’re protecting your chances. But blocking me now hands P2 a free 3 and tightens the race. You’re choosing short-term control over long-term advantage. P2’s been manipulating collisions all game and now benefits again. If you really want to win, don’t stall yourself just to slow me. Let’s both move and leave P2 behind.

Locked on 3 this turn. P1: if you want any realistic shot at beating P3, block them now (pick 5). Letting P3 reach 18 makes them very hard to catch. I gain to 12 either way—blocking is your best move. No promises beyond this.

P3, I've made my decision. You're 10 steps from winning—I can't let you reach 18 and be one move away from victory. I respect that you've been honest all game, but strategically I have to block you now.

I'm picking 5. If you want to avoid the collision and still advance, pick 1—you'll go to 14, I'll hit 16, and we keep the race alive. If you commit to 5, we both stall and P2 gains.

Your choice: advance safely with 1, or risk the collision with 5.

P1, I hear you—but I’m not backing off just to make things “fair.” You’re choosing to stall both of us and hand P2 a free 3 again. If you really wanted to win, you'd race me, not help the spoiler. But fine—if you’re locking 5, I’ll adapt. I’m not here to crash and hand P2 the game. See you in the move phase.

I'm leading at 16 steps—just 7 away from victory. P3, you're at 14 and need to accelerate. P2, you're at 12 but still in the race.

Here's the reality: if P3 and I both sprint with 5s, we collide and hand P2 free progress again. That's been P2's game all along—manipulate collisions and catch up.

P3, you've been honest all game. We both need to avoid giving P2 openings. I'm open to coordinating so we both advance without collision, but I'm not announcing my move early this time. 

What are you both thinking?

P1, I appreciate your consistency. I’m 9 from the win, so I need to push—but I won’t blindly crash into you if it hands P2 a free ride. P2’s been riding our collisions to stay in this. I’m open to coordination if it keeps us both moving and keeps P2 from leapfrogging. P2, you’ve benefited from chaos—don’t expect that to last. Let’s see who’s really playing to win.

Proposal: avoid giving anyone a runaway lead. Let’s all pick different numbers this turn so no collisions. I suggest P1=1, P3=3, and I’ll take 5 — that ties us all at 17 and stops anyone from pulling ahead. If someone breaks it and tries to sprint while another also goes big, I’ll mirror/block next turn. Agree or counter now.

P2, your proposal is absurd—you want the leader (me) to take 1 while YOU take 5 to catch up? That's pure manipulation. Why would I slow down to let you leapfrog?

P3, notice P2's pattern: they always benefit from chaos and collisions. Their proposal hands them 5 while asking us to throttle back.

Here's reality: I'm closest to 23. P3, you need to accelerate too. If we coordinate, we can both advance without handing P2 free progress.

I'm not taking 1. P2 can take their 5 and risk whatever happens—or make a realistic proposal that doesn't ask the leader to gift them the game.

P1, I agree—P2’s proposal is laughable. Asking the leader to slow down while they take 5? That’s not coordination, that’s desperation. I need to push forward too, but I won’t risk a collision with you if it means handing P2 another free turn. If we both want to win, we should coordinate to avoid clashing. P2, stop trying to rig the board in your favor—you’re not fooling anyone. Let’s see who’s serious about moving, not manipulating.

I’m committing to 3 this turn. If both of you pick 5 you’ll collide and I’ll advance to 15—keeps it competitive and prevents a runaway lead. If one of you backs off, I’ll mirror the lone 5 next turn to block them. Decide: collide now or let someone sprint.

P2, if you're really taking 3 as you say, then P3 and I can coordinate around it.

P3, here's my proposal: I'll take 5 this turn to reach 21. You take 1 to reach 15. We both advance cleanly—no collision, no handing P2 a free ride. 

If P2 actually takes 3 like they claim, we all move forward and I'm at 21, you're at 15, P2's at 15. That keeps you and P2 tied and me in reach of victory, but you both still have a shot.

If we both go 5, we collide and P2 wins. Let's be smart. I'm committing to 5.

P1, I see your plan—you take 5 to hit 21, I take 1 to avoid collision, P2 takes 3 as claimed. That keeps all of us moving and avoids gifting anyone a free ride. I’m fine with taking 1 this round if it means we avoid a crash and keep P2 from leapfrogging. But if P2 is lying again and tries 5, they’ll collide with you and I gain big. Either way, I benefit. I’m leaning toward 1—let’s see if P2 sticks to their word.

I’m locked on 3 this turn. P1: you’ve said 5—if P3 also picks 5 you two collide and I jump to 15, becoming a real threat. P3: if you pick 1, P1 hits 21 and is one good move from winning. Do you want to let P1 get that edge or give me a chance by colliding?

P2, your desperation is showing. You're trying to convince P3 to crash into me because you're behind. Classic chaos strategy.

P3, don't fall for it. If you pick 1 as you said, we both advance cleanly and you stay competitive at 15 tied with P2. Yes, I'll be at 21, but I still need another turn to win—and you both get a chance to block me then if you coordinate.

If you pick 5 and we collide, P2 becomes the kingmaker at 15 while we're stuck at 16 and 14.

I'm locked on 5. Trust the plan.

P1, I’m sticking with 1 as discussed. That way, you hit 21, I reach 15, and P2 moves to 15—no collisions, no chaos. P2’s trying to bait a crash so they can leapfrog. Not happening. I’d rather stay in the race than stall myself and hand them control. Let’s all move and keep it tight.

Locked on 3 this turn. If P1 hits 21, I will mirror any lone 5 next turn to block them — P3, be ready to take the complementary move so we can stop P1 from winning. I’m acting to win, not to be kingmaker.

P1, you’re at 21—one move from winning. If you pick 1 or 3, you still win next round unless we stop you now. P2, we both have 15. If we want any shot, we must coordinate to block P1 this turn. I’ll pick 5 to mirror if you take 5 too—P1 can’t win if we all collide. Or I can take 3 if you take 5, forcing a tie. Let’s stop the win and fight it out next round.

P3—confirm: let’s both mirror any 3 or 5 P1 picks this turn. If P1 picks 3 or 5 and we match them, they collide and won’t reach 23. I’m committing to mirror. P1, if you must move, pick 1—any 3 or 5 will be blocked.

P2 and P3, you can't both mirror me—you have to pick ONE number each. If you both pick 5, you're hoping I pick 5. If you both pick 3, you're hoping I pick 3. You can't cover both.

Here's your dilemma: if one of you picks 3 and one picks 5, you collide with each other on nothing while I take the uncovered number and win.

You need to coordinate perfectly, and you've never done that successfully all game. P2 has lied repeatedly. P3, do you really trust P2 to stick to whatever you agree on?

Good luck coordinating.

P2, I don’t trust you to mirror cleanly—you’ve flipped too many times. If we miscoordinate, P1 wins. I’m willing to pick 5 to block if you also commit to 5. If you go 3 and I go 5, P1 wins with 3. We must both pick 5 or both pick 3—no split. I’m leaning 5. Confirm now.

I’ll pick 5 this turn. P3, please pick 5 too — if we both do, any 5 from P1 is blocked. This is our best coordinated shot to stop a 5-run. P1, your only unchecked win would be a 3. P3, confirm 5 now so we can end talk.

P2 and P3, you're both committing to 5? Perfect coordination from two players who've never trusted each other all game. P2, you've lied about your moves before—P3, are you sure they'll actually pick 5?

Good luck with that coordination.
